dc:description:
The relationship between PNPT1 and Leigh syndrome spectrum was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of February 26, 2020. The PNPT1 gene encodes the mitochondrial polynucleotide phosphorylase (PNPase), which localizes to the mitochondrial intermembrane space and functions in RNA import into the mitochondria.

The PNPT1 gene was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Leigh syndrome spectrum in 2012 (PMID: 23084291). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included three variants identified in three cases in three publications (PMIDs: 23084291, 28645153, 30046113). Loss of function is implicated as the mechanism of disease. This gene-disease association is also supported by biochemical function, expression, functional alteration in patient cells, and model systems (PMIDs: 20691904, 27759031, 23084291).

In summary, there is moderate evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the NICHD U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on February 26, 2020 (SOP Version 7).

evidence.dc:description: Variant located in the catalytic domain; patient fibroblasts from demonstrated an accumulation of dsRNA (J2 signal) that was not observed in control cells (Fig. 3b). Moreover, this dsRNA colocalized with mitochondria (Fig. 3b, inset). The accumulation of dsRNA is thought to trigger an interferon mediated, antiviral response.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
NMR spectroscopy: lactate peak, Hyper-lactatemia, 
Brain imaging showed anomalies of putamen and basal ganglia
IUGR, congenital cateract, feeding difficulties, deafness, truncal hypotonia, nystagmus
Died at 2 years. 
Multiple RC deficiency in muscle and fibroblasts

evidence.dc:description:
In silico data predict both to have a deleterious effect on gene  and are located in highly conserved residues within the catalytic site (molecular modelling).
Functional: Patient cultured myoblasts, compound heterozygous for the variants,  showed a reduction in  the respiratory chain complexes CI and CIV, phenotype rescued with retroviral transduction with a wildtype construct. (figure 3).

evidence.rdfs:label: Subject 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Leigh syndrome (neuropathology confirmation)
infantile spasms, hypotonic, had feeding problems, facial hypomimia, dystonic and athetotic movements of the body, mouth and tongue, elevated blood lactate, bilateral signal intensity of globus pallidus, nystagmus, episodes of vomiting, daily seizures

At the age of one month, when the subject was first investigated, she was irritable, hypotonic, had feeding problems, facial hypomimia, dystonic and athetotic movements of the body, mouth and tongue. 
Labs showed elevated blood lactate (2,8 mmol/l) and pyruvate (111mmol/l) with normal levels of creatine kinase, ammonia, liver and kidney enzymes, urine organic acids and plasma and urine amino acids. 
CSF lactate, protein, glucose and amino acids were normal. At the age of two months she was diagnosed with infantile spasms. 
Brain MRI at two months of age showed bilateral signal intensity of globus pallidus, suggestive of Leigh syndrome (Fig. 1A and B).
Biochemical analysis of mitochondrial respiratory chain (RC)from muscle biopsy sample showed cytochrome c oxidase (COX) deficiency. 
At sixmonths of age she smiled and reacted to sounds, fixed her gaze to faces, but was extremely hypotonic and did not follow with eyes. At the age of ten months she had nystagmus and dystonic tongue and upper limb movements. She had episodes of vomiting and daily seizures, which were controlled with combined phenobarbital and vigabatrin treatment. She had very little development or active movements, and she died at the age of two years and five months during an infection.

Neuropathology was consistent with Leigh: subcortical, brainstem and cerebellar atrophic and degenerative features. The striatum/putamen, substantia nigra and cerebellar cortex were severely affected, but also a slight subacute necrotizing feature could be observed in the typical tegmental region in the medulla oblongata as well. (Fig 1C-F).

evidence.dc:description:
Variant located in exon 13.  This change is predicted to be probably damaging and deleterious by PolyPhen and SIFT software respectively, located in conserved domain, residue conserved from human to c.elegans. Absent from 100 controls.  
Functional: Wild type PNPase assembles into a homo-oligomeric complex consisting of a trimer or a dimer of trimers. Patient fibroblasts showed 50% reduction in PNPase, no PNPase complex (260kDa in wild type cells) could be detected in the mitoplast fraction from subject 1 fibroblasts suggesting that the substitution encoded by c.1160A>G disrupts the trimerization of the protein (figure 2B).

evidence.rdfs:label: Subject 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
fixed severe encephalomyopathy, choreoathetotic movements, combined respiratory-chain defects, elevated palsma and cerebrospinal fluid lactate, severely hypotrophic, dystonia, dyskinesia, global hypotonia, severe muscle weakness, no head control, permanent bucofacial dyskinesias
Presented with vomiting, poor eating, and swallowing difficulties of unexplained origin, and she could never sit unaided. At 9 months of age, she suddenly developed trunk hypotonia with disorganized, asynchronic, and erratic dystonic and choreoathetotic movements of all four limbs and bucofacial dyskinesias. She lost purposeful hand movements and could no longer hold her bottle. When she was first referred, she was a 10-year-old bed- and wheel-chair-bound, severely hypotrophic girl (weight ¼ 17 kg [ 3 standard deviations (SDs)]; OFC ¼ 49 cm [ 2.5 SDs]). She could neither stand nor sit unaided. Her voluntary movements were slow and markedly hampered by dystonia, dyskinesia, and choreoathetosis.
She had global hypotonia, severe muscle weakness, no head control, and permanent bucofacial dyskinesias. Deep-tendon reflexes of the inferior limbs were barely detected, owing to muscle atrophy and permanent abnormal movements, but her nerve-conduction
velocity was reduced (32–35 m/s; controls ¼ 40–45 m/s). She could not speak, but she understood and obeyed simple orders. She was otherwise fully conscious and alert, and she could smile, burst out laughing, and follow with her eyes with a direct gaze and no abnormal eye movements. Major swallowing difficulties required gastrostomy, and major retractions of the right hip and ankles prompted a consideration of multiple tenotomies. 
Brain MRIs (axial T2, fast-spin-echoweighted images)  showed hyperintensities in the bilateral putamen and caudate nuclei. (Fig 1 A-S1)
Electroencephalographic evidence of clinically silent erratic myoclonies was noted. 
Decrease in the activity of RC complexes III and IV was found in the liver of subject 1.

evidence.dc:description: Phenotype of the knockout tissue confirms role of PNPase1 in the mitochondria and the association with mitochondrial dysfunction. Tissue specific biochemical recapitulation
evidence.rdfs:label: Conditional KO mouse (liver)

evidence.dc:description: Patient fibroblasts show reduced translation of mitochondrial proteins, this phenotype was also observed when control cells transfected with PNPT1 siRNA. Consistent with a reduction of small RNA import into mitochondria and loss of function mechanism.  Reduced points as only 2 replicates and 1 patient cell line used.

Patient Fibroblasts showed a mitochondrial-translation deficiency, Figure 5. Pulse chase experiments used to measure relative levels of mitochondrial protein translation. Translation reduced in patient fibroblasts, translation is rescued when the patient fibroblast cell line is transfected with a wild type PNPT1 construct. Similar results observed with a control cell line and PNPT1 siRNA.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient fibroblast; mtDNA translation deficiency

evidence.dc:description: Patient fibroblasts show reduced import of two mitochondrial RNAs which is rescued by overexpression of wild type PNPT1 construct, consistent with known function of PNPT1. Reduced points as only 2 replicates and 1 patient cell line used.

By RNA hybridization (northern blot) experiments showed a significant decrease in 5S rRNA and MRP-related RNA import into mitochondria in patient fibroblasts (homozygous for p.Gln387Arg variant) ; mitoblast fraction compared with whole cell lysate fraction, figures 3 and 4.    Overexpression of the wild-type PNPT1 cDNA in fibroblasts of subject 1 induced an increase in 5S rRNA import in mitochondria Figure 3A).
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient cells, altered RNA import

evidence.dc:description: as per scoring rubriac >10 genes in a shared pathogenic pathway.

Fig 3 PNPASE Augments the Import of RNase P, 5S rRNA, and MRP RNAs into Yeast Mitochondria. Radiolabeled RNase P, MRP, 5S rRNA, and GAPDH human RNAs were in vitro transcribed and then incubated with yeast mitochondria expressing PNPASE or an empty vector control. Non-imported RNA was digested with nuclease, followed by RNA isolation, separation on a urea acrylamide gel, and autoradiography. Experiments showed small RNAs imported into yeast mitochondria expressing PNPASE(PNPT1) but not vector only. Consistent data was obtained with mouse embryonic fibroblasts from wild type or PNPT1 knockout strains incubated with radiolabelled small RNAs (figure 7)
evidence.rdfs:label: Transcription/translation of mtDNA

evidence.dc:description: Mitochondrial localisation of PNPT1 consistent with mitochondrial defects observed in disease phenotype.

Figure 1 shows exogenously expressed PNPT1 colocalises to the mitochondria in HEK293 cells. Mitoplast fractionation from mouse liver tissue confirmed intermembrane space of mitochondria, radiolabel experiments showed PNPT1 is imported into the IMS from the cytoplasm.
evidence.rdfs:label: PNPT1 localisation
